loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Fatmata is 40 years old and married with 3 children between the ages of 4 and 11 years. She runs a domestic product shop in Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business since 2007 and sells glass cups, knives and food containers within her community. She says that the main problem facing her business is the sometimes slow purchasing power.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale

loans.name: Hakob

texts.en:
Hakob is a young, private entrepreneur from Yerevan city. His family consists of his parents, his sister and his brother. 

Hakob is the only breadwinner of the family. He runs a retail shop of sunglasses and different accessories. The assortment of goods he sells in the store is not that big. Hakob currently needs to expand it a bit in order for his small business to be competitive and to function in a sustainable way. 

Hakob needs a loan of USD 1,500 to purchase accessories and sunglasses to resell in his store. As this is Hakob’s first loan, it has been approved within the framework of the new joint initiative of Kiva and SEF. The first-chance loan program provides loans to people who did not have access to credit products before because they have no credit history. 

Hakob will be very thankful to the lenders for their good will in supporting him to develop his small business.

loans.use: to purchase accessories and sunglasses to resell in his store.

loans.name: Racheal

texts.en:
Racheal lives in the coastal region of Kenya with her family: her husband and their ten children. She lives in her own house that has neither piped water nor electricity.

She sells timber to passersby and neighbors.She has been in this business for the last five years. She cites seasonality and transportation costs as her major challenges.

Racheal is requesting a loan to purchase more timber for resale. She expects to do this without any difficulties and to continue working without any problems.

loans.use: to purchase more timber for resale.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 27 years old and he is a married businessman with two children. 

He is a tailor and that is what he does for daily bread. He has been in the business for the last five years and the business is doing great despite the usual challenge of competition. 

He knew Milango through a friend who invited him and he joined. He now seeks a loan to buy cloth material for the shop. The extra income that he will raise will improve his living standards and he will also pay school fees for the children.

loans.use: to buy cloth material.

loans.name: Emik

texts.en:
Emik is 55 years old and he lives in Kajaran city. Emik is married and he has two children (a daughter and a son). His daughter is already married and she lives separately with her family. 

Emik has two higher education degrees. First, he graduated from the Pedagogical State Institute in Goris City, the department of Mathematics and Physics. Then, he graduated from the Yerevan State Polytechnic Institute, the department of Industrial Electronics. Now, Emik works at the local electricity networks as a head of the customer service department. Recently, as the result of many years of saving, Emik managed to repair his flat.
 
Emik asks for a loan of 500,000 Armenian drams in order to buy switches, fuse boxes and electrical cords since all of these are worn out and need to be changed.

loans.use: to buy switches, fuse boxes and electrical cords since all of these are worn out and need to be changed.

loans.name: Furaha

texts.en:
Furaha is married, and has five school-going children. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for the family and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a poultry-selling business. She sells to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is the high cost of transportation to her place of operation.

With the 30,000 KES, Furaha wants to purchase chicks and chicken feed. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to purchase chicks and chicken feed.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael has had two previous loans that he was able to repay without challenges. His business improved after the previous loan and he was able to take his children to school. 

There have been challenges though, and the major ones are the low season and price changes. 

In five years time he wants to be running a restaurant, and to do that he is seeking another loan to buy a bicycle and food to stock in the shop. Extra income will improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy a bicycle and food to stock.

loans.name: Edwina

texts.en:
Edwina lives in New Kru town.  She is 33 years old, single, and has three children between 3 to 15 years old, all in school and living at home. 

Edwina was unfortunate in not being able to attend school, but she has been keeping herself busy with business over the past 12 years selling palm oil, beans, imported oil, etc., in the local market. She started this business with a little money from her mother. 

She said that fewer goods on her table are the only business challenge she faces now. She likes her business because it is affordable, and she learned this way of selling from her friends. 

She said I am proud of my business because it is the only means of I and my family surviving.   With the loan, she is going to buy more palm oil, beans, imported oil, etc., to resell.  

Her plan is to increase her sales even more.

loans.use: to buy more palm oil, beans, imported oil, etc., to resell.

loans.name: Miatta

texts.en:
Miatta lives in New Kru town. She is 42 years old and she is married. She has four children between 26 and 16 years old. Two are in school and live at home. 

She did not go to school, so she decided to keep herself busy with business by selling food like peanuts, pepper, beans, etc. to improve her life. She started this business with a little money from her husband eight years ago. She said that fewer goods on her table are the only challenge she faces now. She likes her business because is affordable, and she learned this way of selling from her friends. 

She said she is proud of her business because it is the only means she has of helping her children. She said that with the loan she is going to buy more peanuts, pepper, beans, etc. to resell. Her plan is to increase her sales even more.

loans.use: to buy more peanuts, pepper, beans, etc. to resell.

loans.name: Sargis

texts.en:
Sargis is from Armavir town. He lives with his wife and two children (his son is 21 years old and his daughter is 13 years old). 

Sargis sustains his living by trading tuff stones. He purchases stones from a tuff quarry of the Aragatsotn region and sells them to local people in Armavir town. Sargis has also a big number of customers in Yerevan town. He has been doing this business for 15 years. Sargis's wife works at a local school as a teacher and tries to help her husband in sustaining the family's living. 

Currently Sargis and his family are facing financial big difficulties. Sargis has no money for purchasing tires for his truck so he is asking this loan.

He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. Sargis will be very grateful to lenders for supporting him to buy new tires.

loans.use: to pay for tires.

loans.name: Siranush

texts.en:
Siranush is 48 years old. She lives in Gavar city which is in Gegharkunik region. She has studied at the Gavar city Industrial College.  

Siranush is married and she has two sons; her elder son lives and works in the Russian Federation and the smaller son lives with them and works as a deliverer at the local major company of mineral water production. 

Siranush’s husband in unemployed and, together with his wife, he is engaged in farming and agriculture. They have a small and cute farm where they are raising two calves, two piglets and 20 chickens. They also cultivate beans, potatoes, tomatoes and cabbage. Siranush manages to sell the gathered harvest at their local wholesale market, but the income from their vegetable garden hardly covers their family's needs, so their wish to enlarge their farm with several animals still remains unrealized. 

Siranush has decided to ask a loan of 600,000 Armenian drams in order to buy several piglets and start swine breeding, and she also wants to buy animal fodder for the coming winter. Her four loans from Nor Horizon Siranush have been successfully paid back and she waits for this loan impatiently to enlarge her farm.

loans.use: To buy several piglets and fodder.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 34 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 3 children who are all currently in school. For the past 4 years, Rose has been working hard to manage her boutique, selling clothes. 

To help expand her business, Rose has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more clothes to sell, and will help Rose to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Rose hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another branch of the same business. 

Rose is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Rose, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Armenuhi

texts.en:
Armenuhi is from Metsamor town, where she lives with her husband, mother-in-law and two children. She works as a nurse in a local clinic and provides medical services from her house. As the village is not rich with clinics and hospitals, people need a medical specialist who is able to provide needed services right from her house.
 
Due to her kindness and hard work, Armenuhi is in great demand among both local villagers and people from nearby villages. Now this hardworking woman needs financial assistance to be able to renovate her electrocardiography machine and provide cardiac checks to her clients.

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business startup loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products, so this loan is very important for Armenuhi and she hopes for lenders' support.

loans.use: to pay for renovation of electrocardiography machine

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen lives in Kilifi, Kenya. She is 23 years old and single. Hellen owns a cosmetics shop and a clothes business that she started three years ago. Her business has been doing well. 

Hellen learned of Milango Financial Services through friends, who invited her to join so that they could save and be able to access credit to fund their business. Now, Hellen seeks a loan to buy cloth material, shoes and weaves to sell. The major challenges that Hellen faces are high fuel and transportation costs.

In the next five years, Hellen hopes that her business will grow to be stable. She will use the extra income to increase her savings.

loans.use: buy cloth material, shoes and weaves.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 30 years old. She is married to a local businessman and they have 2 children, ages 8 and 15. Her children are currently attending school and live at home. 

Esther was fortunate to complete 9th grade, but she has been busy running her table where she sells cosmetics in the local market. With the loan proceeds, she will buy more cosmetics for her business. Fewer goods is her challenge. With a little money from her mother, Esther managed to establish this business 6 years ago, and learned by seeing other business people. She enjoys the flow of customers and the fast buying. Her plan is to move from a table business to a shop business and live better lives in the future.

loans.use: buy more cosmetics for her business.

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega County. Kakamega County is located in Western Kenya, close to the Ugandan border. It contains the only tropical rain forest in Kenya, and the variety of the flora in the region makes it well suited for beekeeping. Kakamega County has one of the highest rural population densities in the world (in some areas, close to 600 people per square kilometer), which may contribute to the region's high poverty rates.

David is married, and has seven children. Both he and his wife have been farming for fifteen years.  They currently do dairy farming as well as tend to a tea plantation. David wanted to become a beekeeper because “I love honey as medicine, the income that comes from it and [there is] no hard work when it comes to beekeeping.”

This is David’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to expand his farming activities. His hope for the future is to invest in a good house for himself and his family.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Davit

texts.en: Davit is 24 years old. He lives in Yerevan with his mother, father and retired grandmother. His elder brother and sister are already married and they live in the Russian Federation with their families. Davit works at the bookmaker office as an administrator. His mother does not work and his father is a shoemaker, but unfortunately recently he has had some health problems. These problems are serious ones, since it is connected with his heart. After the last examination, the doctor declared that Davit’s father needs to have an urgent operation. This is a great and unpleasant surprise for Davit and his family, so Davit asks for a loan of 500,000 Armenian drams in order to pay for his father’s for cardiac surgery.

loans.use: to pay for his father’s for cardiac surgery

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 38 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has five children who are currently in school. For the past 12 years, Margret has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food.

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more food in the restaurant to sell, and will help Margret generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Margret hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business into a motel. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.


"

loans.use: to stock more food for the restaurant.

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 46 years old and lives in New Kru town, which is one of the oldest communities in Liberia. Living conditions there are bit difficult due to the high rate of crime, fewer bathrooms, filthy conditions and over-population, but the most interesting part is that rooms are a bit cheaper, there are options of traveling, it has one of the biggest markets in Liberia and food costs less.    

Annie is a widow with three children whose ages are between 7 and 22; only two of her children are currently attending school and live at home. She was unfortunate to attend school, but she has been busy running her shop, which sell soft drinks. With the loan proceeds, Annie will buy more soft drinks for her business. She works 10 hours each day of the week. With a little money from her mother, Annie managed to establish this business 7 years ago. She enjoys the flow of customers. She plans to move from a shop business to a store business.

loans.use: buy more soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Arnold

texts.en:
Arnold lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega is located in Western Kenya, and is famous for the Kakamega Forest, the only tropical rain forest in Kenya. It is a very good location for beekeeping due to the old grown trees in the forest, and concentration of farms in the area, which provide bees with a variety of forage. 

Arnold is married and has six children. His wife works as a teacher, while Arnold farms their land. He has been farming for twenty five years, and is currently farming some crops as well as raising cattle. He likes beekeeping because it is a source of income that will allow him to further profit from his land. 

This is Arnold’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his beehives to pay for his children’s school fees.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is an area that does not suffer from a dry season. She has three children and has been dairy farming for twelve years. Her primary income source is milk.

Beatrice stated what is most enjoyable about farming is "milking and digging" and that her biggest challenge is "climate change." Animals on the farm have been given the names of "Nyota."

Beatrice was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied, "Better service."  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi Kilimo's required micro-finance training session and she said, "Low interest rate."

Beatrice's highest monthly expense is school fees. When asked how the loan will benefit her family, Beatrice replied, "Milking and manure."

As part of Juhudi Kilimo's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Beatrice owns a cow but does not own a pig, poultry, a pump, a bicycle, a motorcycle, or an automobile. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household a mosquito net, but does not have electricity, solar power, running water, a sewing machine, a TV, or a DVD.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Diah

texts.en:
Diah is a Balinese artisan who specializes in handcrafted jewelry. She would like to invest in the purchase of silver and natural gemstones for production in time for the holiday season.

Diah has been selling through NOVICA since 2012. This is her story:

"I was born in Celuk, renowned for its silversmith legacy. When women get married here, we move to the man's house and follow what our husband decides. Luckily, my husband and his parents taught me to design and craft silver jewelry. My designs reflect me and the beauty I find in life. Jewelry to me is about being a woman, and every woman wants to feel beautiful."

A message from Diah: "I want to thank all of you for supporting me with this micro-credit to make my business grow - it means a lot to me. May God bless you all."

loans.use: to invest in the purchase of silver and natural gemstones for production in time for the holiday season.

loans.name: Jasmena

texts.en:
Jasmena is a nurse from Metsamor town. She has been providing medical services to locals for 15 years. Due to her hard work, Jasmena currently has many clients who prefer only her services. She provides different types of medical services including immunization, blood pressure measurement, etc. 

Now, Jasmena needs financial support in order to purchase an electrocardiography machine so as to provide cardiac checking service to her patients. 

She has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF International. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. So this loan is very important for Jasmena and she hopes for the lenders' trust and support.

Jasmena has three grown up children who are married and live with their families.

loans.use: to pay for an electrocardiography machine.

loans.name: Martin

texts.en:
Martin lives and works outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya, close to the Ugandan border. It contains the only tropical rain forest in Kenya, and the variety of the flora in the region makes it well suited for beekeeping. It has one of the highest rural population densities in the world (in some areas, close to 600 people per square kilometer), which may contribute to the region's high poverty rates.

Martin is married and has five children. Both he and his wife are farmers and are currently tending to cows and poultry on their land. Martin likes beekeeping because it produces good income with little work, and will allow him another source of revenue from his land. 

This is Martin’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to pay his children’s school fees. His hope for the future is to expand his farming activities and be a successful farmer.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Magaret

texts.en:
Magaret lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for having the only tropical rain forest in the country. Most farmers in Kakamega grow maize, but sugarcane, papaya, bananas and tea are also popular crops. The variety of crops grown in the region, as well as the abundance of vegetation in the old growth forest, makes Kakamega particularly attractive for beekeeping. 

Magaret is married and has seven children. Her husband has retired from his job as an agricultural supervisor, and now works with her in farming their land. She has been farming for eighteen years, and is currently growing maize, tending to a tree plantation and doing dairy farming. Magaret likes beekeeping because it does not require extensive experience or hard work to keep bees. 

This is Magaret’s first loan, and she is looking forward to the income from her hives, as “it will help me in doing my dairy farming and other farmings because I am a serious farmer.” 

Her hope for the future is to “do my farming well so that I can earn from it.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Yan Fredy

texts.en:
Yan Fredy is a Peruvian artisan who specializes in handcrafted silver and gemstone jewelry. He would like to purchase silver for his jewelry designs as well as some new tools for his workshop.

Yan Fredy has been selling through NOVICA since 2012. This is his story:

"My father designs and crafts jewelry, and he taught me to love the art of silver. I always loved being in his workshop with him. The old designs, with their infinite forms, icons and the techniques used by our ancestors… these are very interesting and special, due to our country's history and what this means for us Peruvians. The new designs have the versatility and perfect craftsmanship of a piece of jewelry. We must always seek innovation."

A message from Yan Fredy: "I'm grateful for your collaboration in this wonderful opportunity you're giving me. In this way, I can increase my production and be ready for the holiday sales. My thanks to each and every one of you."

loans.use: to purchase silver for his jewelry designs as well as some new tools for his workshop.

loans.name: Chresencia

texts.en:
Chrecencia lives in the Kisii area of Kenya, which is not far from Masai land. She has 2 children and has been doing farm work for 6 years. Her primary income source is milk, which is her personal business.

She stated what is most enjoyable about farming: 'Weeding.' Her biggest challenge is 'Climate change.' Animals on the farm have been given the names of 'Nyangera.'

Chrecencia was asked why she chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan, to which she replied: 'Better service.'  This client was also asked what was learned during Juhudi's required micro-finance training session: 'Low interest.'

Her highest monthly expense is business related. When asked 'How will this loan benefit her family', Crecencia replied 'it will improve their income base.'

As part of Juhudi's loan appraisal process, each borrower's assets are evaluated. Crecencia owns the following: 'cow' but does not own 'pig, poultry, pump, bicycle, motorcycle, automobile'. Juhudi Kilimo also tries to measure any change in living standards based on this loan. This borrower has in the household 'mosquito net' but does not have 'electricity, solar power, running water, sewing machine, TV, DVD'.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa lives in New Kru town. She is 45 years old and married with 6 children, ages between 21 and 30; only two live at home and one is in school. 

For the past four years, she has been operating a small shop where she sells used clothes and slipper. She enjoys the flows of costumers. She started this business by selling around in the communities with the little goods she could afford, and learned this way of selling from her mother who also sells used clothes. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase more used clothes for her business. Her plan is to expand her business even more.

loans.use: to purchase more used clothes for her business.

loans.name: Eliud

texts.en:
Eliud lives on a farm outside of Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for its rain forest. Many farmers in the area grow maize, sugar cane and bananas, with maize being the primary crop. The density of the old growth trees in the Kakamega forest and the variety of crops grown in the area make this an excellent area for beekeeping. 

Eliud is married, and has fifteen children. Both he and his wife are farmers and are currently involved in a variety of farm projects, including sugarcane, trees, maize, a cow, a pig and poultry. He likes beekeeping because “I like honey as medicine and it brings a good income [with] no hard work around it.”

This is Eliud’s first loan with Kiva, and he plans to use the income from his hives to buy even more hives. His hope for the future is to “educate my kids to a higher level.”

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Muyid

texts.en:
Muyid is 48 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children, with 1 of them currently in school. For the past 16 years, Muyid has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which sells cooked food. 

To help expand her business, Muyid has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to stock more food for the restaurant to sell, and will help Muyid to generate greater profits and buy some basic needs for her home. Muyid hopes that in the future she will be able to make the business grow bigger and educate her children. 

Muyid is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Muyid who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to stock more food for the restaurant to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a Kiva borrower. He describes himself to be God fearing, disciplined and determined. He is a mechanic and operates a motor vehicle repair business where he repairs motor vehicles and also paints them. His primary customers are motor vehicle owners. 

He will use the KES 100,000 loan to add more equipment for spray painting cars and also to buy a water storage facility for family use. He hopes that in the future, he will educate his children and make sure his children have an income of their own. This is his fourth loan with SMEP DTM. The previous loan of KES 40,000 was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to add more equipment for spray painting cars and also buy a water storage facility.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesus

texts.es: Manuel de Jesús de 37 años de edad. Es un hombre trabajador que posee una feliz familia su esposa y su hijo de 2 años y su hija de 3 meses de edad, viven en casa humilde pero propia, Siempre con deseos de superación Manuel ha sido muy entregado al trabajo que es su fuente de ingreso, se desempeña como jornalero cultivando maiz, platano, loroco y chile aunque todo esto en pequeña cantidad . Desea cambiar la tubería de agua potable y reparar la pila y lavadero existente; por esa razón que solicitó a FUSAI un préstamo que le permita comprar los materiales a utilizar como tubos PVC, cemento, arena entre otros. Espera pronto poder realizar los trabajos y brindarle un mejor beneficio a su familia.
texts.en:
Manuel de Jesus is a 37-year-old worker who possesses a happy family, including his wife, a 2-year-old son, and a 3-month-old daughter. They live in a humble house that is their own. 

Always displaying a desire to get ahead, Manuel has been very dedicated to the work that is the source of his income. He works as a day laborer, cultivating corn, plantains, local greens, and chiles, though in small quantities.

Manuel wishes to replace the potable water tubing in his house and repair the current laundry area [seen in the photo]. That is why he is soliciting a loan from FUSAI, to purchase materials such as PVC tubing, cement, and sand, among other supplies. He wants to complete this work and offer the benefits to his family.

loans.use: to replace the water pipes in his home and buy materials needed for installing PVC, including glue and other items.

loans.name: Nubia Yesenia

texts.es: Nubia de 36 años de edad había junto a su familia su esposo y su hijo de 12 años de edad. Gracias a Dios habita en casa humilde pero propia desde hace 2 años. Es una mujer que se gana la  vida como empleada domestica, y cuidando niños. Su deseo es terminar de construir el baño por lo que necesita comprar cemento, ladrillos, arena, grava, hierro y pagar la mano de obra. Espera que con el préstamo que le ha proporcionado FUSAI pueda finalizar dichas obras.
texts.en:
Nubia is 36 years old. She lives with her family, her husband and her 12 year old son. She has lived in a modest but clean house for the past two years, thanks to God. She is a woman who earns her living as a domestic worker, taking care of children. 

Nubia wants to complete the construction of her bathroom. She needs to buy cement, bricks, sand, re-bar and to pay for labor. She hopes that with the loan she has been given by FUSAI she will be able to finish this work.

loans.use: to buy cement, bricks, sand, re-bar and to pay for labor to finish the bathroom in her house.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James lives on a farm close to Kakamega town, in Kakamega county. Kakamega is located in Western Kenya and is famous for the Kakamega Forest, the only tropical rain forest in Kenya. It is a very good location for beekeeping due to the old growth trees in the forest and the concentration of farms in the area, which provide bees with a variety of forage. 

James is married, and has seven children. He and his wife have been farming for twenty years and are currently growing tomatoes, vegetables, maize and sugarcane on their land. He likes beekeeping because it is an income-generating activity, and in the future he hopes to channel some of that income into expanding his land and farming projects.

This is James’ first loan with Kiva and he plans to use the income from his beehives to pay his children’s school fees.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Hovik

texts.en:
Hovik is a taxi driver from Vanadzor town. He lives with his wife, mother, and two little children. Hovik has been providing taxi services for 4 years already. He works day and night to gather income for his family.
 
Currently, Hovik's car needs to be renovated, but unfortunately he has no financial means to do that. Realizing that the income from taxi business is vital for his family, Hovik has decided to apply for the loan and renovate it.
 
He has now been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans, with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. 

The loan is very important for Hovik to be able to renovate his car and purchase tires to be able to continue his taxi driving business.

loans.use: to renovate his taxi and purchase tires to be able to continue his taxi driving business and support his family.

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en:
Joshua is a Kiva borrower. He has 12 children. He describes himself to be determined, visionary and honest. He operates a carpentry where he makes furniture to sell. He will use the KES 100,000 loan to purchase more plywood to make furniture, and buy a water storage facility, since his family faces a challenge of lack of enough water storage facilities. 

He hopes that in the future, his 12 children will be self-dependent. This is his fourth loan with SMEP DTM. Previous loan of KES 40,000 was repaid successfully

loans.use: to buy more plywood for making furniture, and buy a water storage facility.

loans.name: Hadija

texts.en: Hadija lives in Kongowea, Kenya. She is a 43-year-old married business woman with two children who are still in school. She has been running a grocery store in Kongowea for the last four years. This business has been feeding her family and she does everything to make sure that it succeeds despite the competition and funding challenges. She learned about Kiva's partner, Milango Financial Services, through friends, and now she seeks a loan to buy cabbage, kale, tomatoes, and fruit for her grocery store. She will use the extra income that she will earn to improve her living standards and pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: to buy cabbage, kale, tomatoes, and fruit to sell in her grocery store.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Mariatu is 25 years old and married with two children, aged 9 and 13. She runs a palm oil business in Tombo, in a Western rural area in Sierra Leone. She started this business to get her daily living. 

She's been in this business since just after she got married and she sells palm oil within her community. She says that at present her business is doing well because with the profit she was able to take care of her family.

Mariatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more palm oil for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and have a permanent business location. In the future, she would like to expand her business to a higher level. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Baby

texts.en:
Baby is 40 years old and married with four children between the ages of 4 and 15. She runs a domestic product business in Tombo's western rural area in Sierra Leone.

She's started this business after the rebel war, and sells rubber bowls, wax cotton, and food containers with her community.  She says that the main problem in her business is an improper business location.

Baby requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more wax cotton and a variety of food containers to sell. 

She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. 

In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more wax cotton and a variety of food container to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food stuffs like flour and beans.

loans.name: Justo Rolando

texts.es:
Justo  es un hombre casado de 43 años de edad, padre de cuatro hijos de los cuales 2 hombre y 2 mujeres, quienes viven en el Departamento de Sololá. 
El se dedica al cultivo agrícola, sembrando papa a  unos metros de su vivienda. Comenta que lleva 15 años en esta actividad que hasta el momento es rentable y productiva. 
Comenta que desde pequeño sus padres le enseñaron esta labor y gracias a ello el ahora cuenta con un trabajo seguro. A través de lo que realiza obtiene ingresos y ganancias aceptables que le ayudan a contribuir a la economía familiar.
El está solicitando un préstamo de Q 2,000.00 para la compra de semillas de papa y abano químico para poder cultivarlo y así incrementar sus ganancias.
Su sueño es generar más ganancias para poder remodelar su vivienda y así darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Justo is 43 years old. He is married and the father of four children, two male, two female. He lives in Sololá department. He is a farmer, growing potatoes a few meters from his house. He comments that up to now this has been a productive and profitable activity which he has been doing for the past 15 years. He says that his parents taught him how to do this when he was small and thanks to that he has secure work. Work that allows him enough revenue and profit to contribute to the family's economy. 

Justo is requesting a loan of 2,000 GTQ to buy seed potatoes and fertilizer so he can plant them and increase his income. His dream is to generate more income and be able to renovate his house, giving his family a higher quality of living.

loans.use: to buy seed potatoes and fertilizer.

loans.name: Yurik

texts.en:
Yurik is a shoe tailor with 15 years of experience. He lives with his wife in Vanadzor town. 

Near the house where Yurik lives, he owns a small workshop where he tailors and provides different renovation services for shoes.  Currently for tailoring new stock of autumn shoes, Yurik needs financial support. The income that he earns is barely enough for covering family costs, so it is very difficult for Yurik to save money to purchase accessories needed for the work. Additional money from the loan will be also used to renovate the workshop and improving its conditions.

Yurik has been approved for a loan within the framework of a new joint initiative between Kiva and SEF international. The start-up loan program provides business start-up loans with soft conditions to informal businesses that do not have access to credit products. So, for Yurik the loan is very important. 

He hopes for lenders' support; the loan will make a great improvement both in his professional and personal life.

loans.use: to pay for accessories for shoe repair and renovation of the workshop

loans.name: Xecam En Victoria Group

texts.en:
The village of Xecam is located in a mountainous area in the western highlands of Guatemala.
The Friendship Bridge Trust Bank, “Xecam en Victoria,” is located here and consists of seven
hardworking and enthusiastic women. They are beginning their second loan cycle with
Friendship Bridge, funded by KIVA investors. Most of the ladies work in textile production,
including embroidery and weaving, as well as animal husbandry. The income that these women
earn is essential to the maintanence and well-being of their families.

Like all Trust Banks within the Friendship Bridge program, “Xecam en Victoria” has its own
Board of Directors that consists of three women who are charged with leadership responsibilities.
The President for this new loan cycle is Francisca, a 37-year-old woman who is the mother of five
children. She is hardworking and divorced. Because of the income that she earns, Francisca is
able to provide food, healthcare and education for her children. She is optimistic and confident
that she will be able to sustain and grow her small business which involves the resale of
traditional clothing. Because her business is doing well, Francisca is applying for her second loan
cycle which she will use to purchase additional thread and fabric. She already has orders from
potential clients as well as repeat clients in her own community.

Francisca is amazed and delighted that people from other parts of the world want to know her
story and support her as well as the other six ladies in the Trust Bank. She truly appreciates the
confidence of the KIVA investors. In her own words, "Women are able to change their lifestyle,
but in order for that to happen, we need some help. It is so important for us to generate an
income for our families. I so appreciate the kindness and support that Friendship Bridge and
KIVA share with us.”

loans.use: to purchase additional thread and fabric.

loans.name: Jeanne D'arc Marie

texts.fr: Jeanne D'arc est une femme de 53 ans célibataire, mère d'un enfant de 5 ans qui va déjà à l'école. Elle est commerçante depuis 4 ans dans la capitale où elle vend le carburant en détail dans les bouteilles d'un litre. c'est grâce à ce petit commerce qu'elle prend soin d'elle et de sa petite famille. Elle aimerai augmenter le montant de son capital pouvoir acheter plusieurs bidons de carburant cela lui permettra de réaliser un plus gros bénéfice qu'elle économisera pour ouvrir une petite boutique, et s'occuper de son fils.
texts.en: Jeanne D'arc is a 53-year-old woman who is unmarried and the mother of a 5-year-old child, already in school. Jeanne D'arc has been a merchant for four years in the capital, where she sells fuel retail in 1-liter bottles. Thanks to this small business, she take cares of herself and her small family. She would like to increase her capital to be able to purchase more containers of fuel. This will enable her to make a bigger profit, which she will save to open a small store and take care of her son.

loans.use: to  buy containers of fuel to sell retail

loans.name: Juana Elena

texts.es: Juana Elena es una señora viuda, trabaja todos los días para pagar sus necesidades diarias y del hogar. Se dedica a confeccionar ropa y los fines de semana hace comida para vender. Con las ganancias que le genera su actividad ha venido haciendo pequeñas mejoras en su hogar. Solicita este crédito para construir el muro perimetral del lado norte de su vivienda, iniciara la primera etapa de  construcción comprando materiales como cemento, piedra cantera, arena, hierro. Esta obra es muy importante para ella ya que la zona donde habita hay presencia delicuencial, por lo que le urge garantizar su seguridad.
texts.en:
Juana Elena is a widow. She works every day to pay her basic needs and household expenses. She sews clothing and on week-ends makes food for sale. With the profits that she makes through these activities she has managed to make small improvements to her house.

Juana Elena is requesting this loan to build a wall along the north perimeter of her property. She will start the first part of construction by buying materiel like cement, quarry stone, sand and re-bar. This project is very important to her as the area she lives in has a crime problem and she wants to guarantee her security.

loans.use: to buy cement, quarry stone, sand and re-bar.

loans.name: Artashes

texts.en:
Artashes is 51 years old and he lives with his family in the village of Zangakatun in Ararat region. For several years he has worked as a linear specialist  at the large local telephone company, but at this moment Artashes is unemployed and he and his wife are engaged in farming and agriculture. Their three sons are already married and Artashes already has three grandchildren.

Artashes is engaged in beekeeping and he also has a very nice colorful fruit garden, mainly pear trees of different sorts. On his farm he breeds a cow, a calf and twenty chickens. He has eleven beehives and he manages to sell very tasty and pure honey. His garden harvest and honey he sells at the local wholesale market with the help of his wife.

Artashes asks for a loan of 600,000 Armenian drams in order to buy several beehives and two more calves.

loans.use: to buy several beehives and two more calves, which will help him to increase the profit from agriculture

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama is in her early 30s and is married with three children between the ages of two and ten. She runs a domestic products business in the Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone.

She has been in this business since 2011 and sells pan sets and wax cotton within her community. She says that her business is doing well because it enables her to take care of her children.

Fatmata requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more wax cotton and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more wax cotton and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Salome

texts.en: Salome lives in the Kongowea area where she runs her business. She is 30 years old, married and a mother of three. Two of her children attend school. She has been in the tailoring business for the last ten years and her business has been growing. She has been able to employ someone to help her run the business. She knew Milango through friends and decided to join so that she could save and access credit to fund her business. She now seeks a loan to buy fabric for sale in her shop. She will use the extra income for the cereals business that she intends to start.

loans.use: to buy fabric.

loans.name: Yeabu

texts.en:
Yeabu is 35 years old and married with three children between the age of six and 12. She runs a retail business in the Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone. 

She started in this business immediately after the war and sells soda, milk, cigarettes and cooking seasonings within her community. She says that the main problem for her business is the lack of capital to expand it.

Yeabu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to further expand her business. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Ramatu

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Ramatu from the Tombo Western rural area in Freetown. She is married with two children who are three and seven years old. One of her children is going to school. After the war, Ramatu established her pharmaceutical business. She began her business because she needed to earn income to support their home. She works at the business ten hours per day and seven days per week. She says that the main challenge is the lack of enough capital to run her business.

Ramatu requires a loan in order to buy more medical drugs, such as malarial drugs, blood syrup, and cholera drugs, for resale. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, Ramatu plans to expand her business further. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more medical drugs such as malarial drugs, blood syrup, and cholera drugs for resale.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet lives in Kongowea and runs a clothing business in the same area. She is 33 years old and married with one child. She has been in the clothing business for the last eight months; her business has been growing. She joined Milango to be able to save and access credit to fund the business. Her challenges in the business are competition and a lack of funding. She knew Milango through friends and now seeks a loan to buy bales of clothes and expand her current business. The extra income that she will earn will improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to buy bales of clothes.

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Mariatu is 35 years old and married with two children age six and 11. She runs a general merchandise business in the Tombo Western rural area in Sierra Leone. 

She's started this business before she got married and sells soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits in her community. She says that the main problem for her business is the lack of capital to expand it.

Mariatu requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and improve her standard of living. In the future, she would like to expand her business further. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more soda, milk, cigarettes and biscuits for resale.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Meet Victoria from Liberia; more precisely she live in New Kru town. She is 40 years old, and single with five children between 14 and 22. Only two are in school and live at home. For the past eight years she has been selling soft drinks. She started this business by selling small amount of oranges in the community. She learned this way of selling from her mother and is now requesting a loan to purchase more soft drinks for her business. Her plans are to expand her business and build a house.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for her business,

loans.name: Adama

texts.en:
Adama is 35 years old and married with two children between the ages of nine and 15. She runs a domestic products business in the Tombo Western rural area of Sierra Leone.

She's been in this business since after the war and sells glasses, knives and food containers within her community.  She says that the main problem for her business is the location.

Adama requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her business and take care of her family. In the future, she would like to open a big shop. She is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more spoons and a variety of food containers for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy bananas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy ten bags of kale.

loans.name: Mamusu

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Mamusu from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is married with four children.  In 2006, Mamusu established her palm oil business. She began her business because she wanted to generate a permanent source of income. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is transportation problems, to travel from one village to another is very difficult.

Mamusu requires a loan in order to purchase more palm oil to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Mamusu plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil to expand her business.

loans.name: Fatmata

texts.en:
Meet 40-year-old Fatmata from Jui eastern area in Freetown. She is widowed with four children between the ages seven years and 28 years.  In 2003, Fatmata established her green vegetable leaf business. She began her business because she wanted to create a permanent source of income so she could take care of the children. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, seven days per week. She says that the main challenges to her business are price inflation and the high cost of transportation.

Fatmata requires a loan in order to purchase more green vegetable leaves to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her status of living and increase her business. In the future, Fatmata plans to expand her business more. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more green vegetable leaves to expand her business.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
Martha lives in New Kru town. She is 43 years old and is a widow with 5 children between 3 and 17 who are in school and live at home.

For the past 8 years she has been operating a small shop where she sells soft drinks. She says sometimes buying goes slowly. She started this business by selling around in the communities with the little goods she would afford and learned this way of selling from her friends.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more soft drinks for her business. Her plan is to expand her business even more.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks for her business

loans.name: Sandro

texts.en:
Sandro came to the States in 1999 from Ecuador, where he studied computer technology. He continued his studies in Morristown, but wasn’t able to complete his degree after two years. At the time, Sandro had started his own computer repair business but put it on hold to work as a full-time painter, which provided more consistent income.

In 2009, Sandro began repairing computers again on nights and weekends using the substantial customer base he had built over the years. Though he still paints during the day, he runs a small computer repair operation out of his basement. His expertise, affordability, and ability to speak both English and Spanish make Sandro’s services appealing to customers.

The funds from this loan will go toward purchasing equipment, such as monitors, hard drives, and cables, to assist the business. Sandro will also invest in marketing materials, such as flyers, in order to attract more clients. Sandro’s long-term goal is to move from his basement into a storefront.

loans.use: To help purchase equipment and marketing materials for a small start-up computer repair business

loans.name: Maria Leonor

texts.es: María Leonor es una mujer soltera quien se dedica a la venta de café y cosa de horno (pan típico nicaragüense)en las paradas de buses y en el barrio donde habita. Con el ingreso de las ventas ha venido construyendo su casita poco a poco. En esta ocasión solicita el crédito para comprar materiales de construcción como cemento, arena y piedrín para reforzar el piso de su vivienda que consta de una capa de cemento deteriorada, con el préstamo podrá repellar las paredes de su casa también. Con dicha inversión mejorará la higiene de su hogar y brindara una mejor apariencia física.
texts.en: Maria Leonor is a single woman who has a business selling coffee and baked goods (traditional Nicaraguan bread) at bus stops and in her neighborhood. With the sales revenue, she has been building her house little by little. This time, she is requesting a loan to buy construction materials such as cement, sand, and gravel to strengthen the floor of her home, which consists of a run-down layer of cement. With this loan, she will also be able to plaster the walls of her house. This investment will improve the cleanliness of her home and will give it a better physical appearance.

loans.use: to buy cement, sand, and gravel.

loans.name: Liz

texts.es:
Liz es de la ciudad de Ybycui, quien está estudiando la carrera de administración de Empresas. Ella es una persona que se está esforzando por salir adelante y ayudar también así a su familia.
Comenta que su meta es ser una buena profesional, y que también pueda ayudar a las demás personas. Quiere salir adelante e ir creciendo.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en el pago de las cuotas de su universidad, y así poder seguir estudiando y estar así mas cerca de cumplir con su meta.
texts.en: Liz is from the city of Ybycui and is studying Business Administration. She is someone who is working hard to get ahead and help her family. She says that her goal is to become a professional and also be able to help others. She hopes to get ahead and continue growing. She is requesting this loan to be able to invest in the payment of her university fees so that she can continue studying and get closer to fulfilling her goal.

loans.use: to pay university fees.

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es: Doña Cándida es madre de dos hijos, soltera, se dedica a administrar una pulpería desde su casa de habitación. Solicita el préstamo para invertir en su negocio y surtir de productos como granos básicos, gaseosas, verduras, productos del aseo personal y de hogar, golosinas, lácteos, enlatados, los cuales son demandados por sus clientes y vecinos del barrio. Su objetivo es aprovechar las ventas de estos últimos tres meses del año, las que se caracterizan por ser las mas altas, con el objetivo de cumplir con los diferentes gastos familiares y pagar el crédito.
texts.en: Candida is a single mother of two children who makes a living running a small store from her home. She is requesting a loan to invest in her business and stock products like basic grains, soft drinks, vegetables, personal hygiene and household cleaning products, snacks, dairy products and canned goods. These goods are demanded by her customers and neighbors. Her objective is to take advantage of the next three months of sales which are characterized for being the busiest sales months. This will allow her to cover her family's expenses and pay the loan back.

loans.use: to buy products including basic grains, soft drinks, vegetables, personal hygiene and household cleaning products, snacks, dairy products and canned goods.

loans.name: Philimena Q.

texts.en: Philimena Q. is 31 years old and lives in Buchanan, the capital city of Grand Bassa County. She is married and her husband is a principal. They have three children ages 8 to 15 years old, all of whom live at home and attend school. For the past fifteen years she has been operating a table where she sells slippers, chain, jeans, etc. She started this business with money from her husband. She enjoys her business because she has lots of customers. She is requesting a loan to purchase more slippers, chain, jeans, etc. for her business. She plans to build a house in the near future.

loans.use: to purchase more slippers, chain, jeans, etc. for her business

loans.name: Vamah

texts.en:
Vamah is 30 years old and lives in Buchanan. She is single and has two children, ages 13 and 16, who are in school and live at home. 

Since 2009, she has been operating a small shop where she sells rice, oil, pepper, etc. She has a lot of customers and she makes a lot of money, which is helping her to look after her children. 

She is requesting a loan to purchase rice, oil, pepper, etc. for her business. In the future, she plans to build her house.

loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, pepper, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria lives in Buchanan. She is 27 years old and married with three children between the ages of 1 and 10. Her children are in school and live at home. Her husband works with a road contractor company. She started this business with money given to her by her mother, and learned it from her.

She is requesting a loan to purchase more fish for her business. Her plans are to buy a piece of land and build a house for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for her business.

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Marta es estudiante de la carrera de Fisioterapia y Kinesiología, comenta que una vez terminada su carrera ella quiere trabajar, realizar post-grados, ser reconocida como una profesional de primera.
Ella es una estudiante muy destacada, que sobresale por el buen desempeño que tiene en la universidad, y es por eso que le va muy bien.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en el pago de sus cuotas, y así estar cada vez más cerca de cumplir con sus metas.
texts.en: Marta is a Physiotherapy and Kinesiology student. She mentions that once she finishes her studies she wants to work, take on her Master's studies and be recognized as a first class professional. She is an outstanding student who excels because of her strong performance at the university. For this reason, school has gone very well for her. She is requesting this loan to be able to pay her university tution and in this way get closer to fulfilling her goals.

loans.use: to pay her tuition.

loans.name: Salomy

texts.en:
Salomy sells food stuffs, such as rice and maize in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has been educated until the end of middle school. She is married and has 5 children. Her husband is a Pastor. 

Salomy has been working in this enterprise for 3 years now. She is responsible for supporting her husband in paying the family's utility bills and their children's school fees. 

Her loan will be used to increase her current stock levels of food stuffs for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand it and increase her capital base. In the long run, she wants to expand her business into the neighboring villages.

loans.use: to increase her current stock levels of food stuff to sell.

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a widow and has a child. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Janet is a successful businesswoman. She sells soft drinks or minerals in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has been actively involved in this business for about a year. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Janet uses her income to provide for the entire family. Janet will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of soft drinks, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Janet plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of soft drinks, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales

loans.name: Jesus

texts.es:
Jesus vive con sus padres en la ciudad de Curuguaty, trabaja en una casa comercial, como vendedor, desde hace 11 meses, está cursando el 1er año de Agronomía, su sueño es llegar a ser un reconocido y talentoso Ingeniero Agrónomo. Su familia es su fortaleza, su madre siempre quiso que estudiara  en la facultad y gracias a su esfuerzo lo está haciendo.
Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de materiales de estudio, ya que los necesita para poder seguir luchando por ser un gran profesional.
texts.en:
Jesus lives with his parents in the city of Curuguaty.  He works in a trade house as a salesman, and has been doing this for eleven months.  He is also finishing up his first year studying Agronomy.  His dream is to become a well-known and talented agricultural engineer.  

He gets his strength from his family.  His mother is the one that always wanted him to study.  Now, thanks to all his hard work and efforts, he is able to continue studying.

He is requesting this loan to buy school supplies.  He needs these items in order to continue fighting towards becoming a great professional.

loans.use: to buy school supplies.

loans.name: Osmar

texts.es:
Osmar actualmente se desempeña como Administrador de çuna buena empresa. El es estudiante, se encuentra cursando el primer  año de la carrera de Ingeniería Comercial, se muestra muy agradecido por el apoyo e interés que recibió, ya que le es de mucha ayuda.
Es es una persona que esta luchando para salir adelante, es por eso que pone todo de si para mejorar. Solicita de este crédito para poder invertirlo en el pago de sus cuotas. Agradece por esta oportunidad que esta recibiendo que le será de mucha ayuda.
texts.en:
Osmaris currently works as an Administrator for a good business. He is also a student who is currently in his first year of a business degree. He is very grateful for the support and interest that he has received because it has been of great help to him. 

Osmar is someone who is working hard to get ahead and it is for this reason that he gives it all in order to improve. He is requesting this loan to pay his tuition. He is thankful for this opportunity that he is receiving because it will be of great help to him.

loans.use: to pay university tuition.

loans.name: Marlon Enrique

texts.es:
Marlon, es un joven de 22 años de edad, vive con su compañera de vida tienen un hijo de un año. Se dedica a la venta de pan en moto oficio que aprendió de un tío y lo realiza desde hace tres años y que ha sabido administrar. 
Ha tomado la decisión de solicitar un crédito para compra de diferentes tipos de pan como donas, quesadillas espécialas y pan integral, de esta manera fortalece su negocio y generara mayores ganancias.
Su sueño es crecer en el negocio para obtener mayores ingresos y así mejorar la calidad de vida que brinda a su familia.
texts.en:
Marlon, 22, lives with his life partner and their one-year-old son. He makes a living selling bread from his motorcycle. He learned this skill from an uncle and has been doing this work for three years as an administrator.

He decided to request a loan to buy different types of bread such as donuts, special quesadillas, and whole wheat bread. This will strengthen his business and generate more income.

His dream is to grow his business to earn more income and improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to buy different types of bread such as donuts, special quesadillas, and whole wheat bread.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Juliana is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling rice and beans in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for two years. 

Juliana is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. 

Juliana wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of rice and beans. In the long term, Juliana plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell more rice and beans

loans.name: Rosalina Del Carmen

texts.es:
Rosalina, tiene 29 años de edad, vive con su esposo, tienen tres hijos pequeños que estudian primaria. Rosalina se dedica a la venta de mariscos, tiene 10 años en el negocio junto a su esposo lo ha realizado, trabajan de lunes a viernes.
Rosalina tiene interés en un préstamo, pues considera que será de ayuda para su negocio, ya que comprara variedad de mariscos (camarones, pescado) y tambien moluscos (calamar, conchas) entre otras especies, el tener el préstamo le dará a ella la capacidad para realizar comprar periódicas y hacer dinámico el negocio. 
Su aspiración es fortalecer el negocio y ofrecer  mejor calidad de producto a los clientes.
texts.en:
Rosalina is twenty-nine years old.  She lives with her husband and they have three small children.  Their kids are all studying in primary school.  Rosalina makes a living selling seafood.  She has been doing this for ten years with her husband, and they work Monday to Friday.

Rosalina is interested in a loan because she thinks it will greatly help her business.  She will buy a variety of seafood and mollusks, including shrimp, fish, squid, oysters, and others.  Having the loan will give her the ability to make regular purchases and to make her business more dynamic.

Her dream is to strengthen her business and to offer the highest quality products to her customers.

loans.use: to buy a variety of seafood and mollusks, including shrimp, fish, squid, and oysters, among others.

loans.name: Jonatan

texts.es:
Jonatan s un joven de 22 años de edad y vive en al ciudad de Chincha. Para poder salir adelante trabaja como almacenero en una pequeña empresa de agroindustrias, el labora alrededor de 9 horas al día y cree que le esta yendo bien en su trabajo porque es muy responsable.

Jonatan está agradecido con los prestamistas kiva ya que gracias a su gran ayuda podrá comprar una moto para poder transportarse, ya que vive en una zona alejada y gasta mucho dinero en movilidad, de esta manera podrá ahorrar y seguir luchando por hacer realidad su gran sueño:” Tener su casa propia”.
texts.en:
Jonatan, 22, lives in the city of Chincha. To make a living, he works as a shopkeeper for a small agro-industry business. He works around nine hours a day and thinks his work is going well because he is very responsible.

Jonatan is grateful for the Kiva loans because thanks to their help, he will be able to buy a motorcycle for transportation. He lives in a remote area so transportation is expensive. Having a motorcycle will save him money and allow him to keep working toward his dream to have his own home.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah operates a small scale chemical store in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education as she is a high school graduate. She is married and has five children.  Sarah has been operating a chemical store for close to four years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of chemical products, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands. She plans on reinvesting profits into the business.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of chemical products, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence sells secondhand clothing in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education as she finished middle school education. She is married and has 2 children. Her husband is a mason. Florence has been selling secondhand clothing for close to 2 years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of secondhand clothing, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to develop her business further and ensure that all her children receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of secondhand clothing, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands.

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: Matilda is married to a mason. She has 2 children. She uses her income to help her husband pay the household expenses as well as save for a rainy day. After she graduated from Junior High School, Matilda decided to enter into a trade. Currently she sells panties and underwear in Fretsi (near Takoradi). With over a year of experience in this trade, Matilda sees an opportunity to expand her enterprise further. However, she does not have the working capital necessary to increase her quantity of stock. Her loan will be used to buy more panties and underwear, indirectly helping her boost her overall sales. Matilda wants to make her business self-sustainable as soon as possible. As a result, she plans to channel the new profits from her expanded business back into her enterprise.

loans.use: to buy more panties and underwear to boost her overall sales.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua is a widow and has 5 children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Ekua is a successful businesswoman. She sells maize in  Dompoase (near Elmina). She has been actively involved in this business for about 40 years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Ekua uses her income to provide for the entire family. 

She will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of maize, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Although she grew up in difficult circumstances, Vida is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling eggs and vegetables in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for a year now. Vida is single without any children. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her support herself and her extended family. Vida wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence, allowing her to sell greater quantities of eggs and vegetables. In the long term, Vida plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus, helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence, allowing her to sell greater quantities of eggs and vegetables

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Sarah is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling fish in Fretsi (near Takoradi). She has been involved in this enterprise for two years. 

Sarah is married and has five children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. 

Sarah will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of fish, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Sarah plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of fish, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Due to difficult circumstances, Aba did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, she sells rice porridge in Dompoase (near Elmina). She has been doing so for about 15 years. As a divorcee with six children, Aba uses all her income to feed and provide for her family. 

She will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of rice to prepare her porridge, which will aid her in improving her overall sales. Aba wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of rice to prepare her porridge.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua is a widow and has 5 children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Ekua is a successful businesswoman. She sells maize  in  Dompoase (near Elmina). She has been actively involved in this business for about five years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Ekua uses her income to provide for the entire family.  

She will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of maize, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a small-scale "wakye" seller. (Wakye is a traditional Ghanaian dish made primarily from beans, rice, and colored leaves.)  She primarily sells her wakye in Dompease (near Elmina). 

She has had some form of formal education, as she is a junior high school  graduate. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a  petty trader.   

Grace  has been preparing and selling wakye for close to seven  years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. 

She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of rice and beans, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demands. 

She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of mounting a wakye stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of rice and beans, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demands.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba is a widow and has 2 children. Even though she did not receive any formal education, Aba is a successful businesswoman. She prepares and sells ‘Banku’ for a living (a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth whitish consistent paste). She normally sells her ‘Banku’ in Dompoase (near Cape Coast). She has been actively involved in this business for about 2 years. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Aba uses her income to provide for the entire family. 

She will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of maize and cassava, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Aba plans to further diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customer preferences.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of maize and cassava, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales.

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Due to difficult circumstances, Adwoa did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Adwoa prepares and sells ‘Banku’ (a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth whitish consistent paste) in Dompoase (near Cape Coast). She has been doing so for a number of years. As a widow with 4 children, she uses all her income to provide for her family. 

She will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of maize and cassava, which will aid her in improving her overall ‘Banku’ sales. Adwoa wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of maize and cassava, which will aid her in improving her overall ‘Banku’ sales.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Due to difficult circumstances, Efua did not have access to any form of formal education, yet this has not stopped her from achieving her dream of becoming an entrepreneur. Currently, Efua sells maize in Dompoase (near Elmina). She has been doing so for about 7 years. As a divorcee with six children, Efua uses all her income to feed and provide for her family.  

She will use the loan to purchase an increased amount of maize, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.  Efua  wants to use the future profits from her expanded business to ensure that all her children are able to receive an education.

loans.use: to purchase an increased amount of maize, which will aid her in improving her overall sales.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education,  Efua is an entrepreneur. She specializes in preparing and selling "banku" (a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water into a smooth, whitish consistent paste). 

She usually sells her banku in Wakrom (near Cape Coast). She has been involved in preparing and selling banku for four years. 

Efua  is married and has six children. Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees.  

Efua wants to use her loan to purchase a greater quantity of cassava and maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels. As a result, this will allow her to sell greater quantities of her tasty banku. 

In the long term, Efua plans to reinvest the future profits back into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.
